017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ycwcm;
018
019import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.FloatColors;
020import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.MathTools;
021import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.BitConversion;
022
023import java.util.Random;
024
025/**
026 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the YCwCm color space.
027 */
028public class ColorTools {
029        /**
030         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, Y (luma or lightness), Cw
031         * (chromatic warmth), Cm (chromatic mildness), and A (alpha or opacity).
032         * Luma should be between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for
033         * very light colors (almost only white). The two chroma values range from 0.0 to 1.0, and there's some aesthetic
034         * value in changing just one chroma value. When warm is high and mild is low, the color is more reddish, when both
035         * are low it is more bluish, when mild is high and warm is low, the color tends to be greenish, and when both are
036         * high it tends to be brown or yellow. When warm and mild are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.  Alpha
037         * is the multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
038         * <br>
039         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as luma,
040         * warm, and mild, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original Y, Cw, and Cm
041         * values if the original values were a valid YCwCm color and not an "imaginary color." {@link #fromRGBA(float)}
042         * should always produce a valid YCwCm color.
043         *
044         * @param luma       0f to 1f, luma or Y component of YCwCm, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
045         * @param warm       0f to 1f, "chroma warm" or Cw component of YCwCm, with 1f more red or yellow
046         * @param mild       0f to 1f, "chroma mild" or Cm component of YCwCm, with 1f more green or yellow
047         * @param alpha      0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque 
048         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
049         */
050        public static float ycwcm(float luma, float warm, float mild, float alpha) {
051                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (mild * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
052                                | ((int) (warm * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (luma * 255) & 0xFF));
053        }
054
055        /**
056         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
057         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
058         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
059         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
060         */
061        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
062        {
063                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed), y = (decoded & 0xff),
064                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff),
065                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >> 1);
066                return Math.min(Math.max(y + (cw * 5 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) << 24
067                                | Math.min(Math.max(y - (cw * 3 >> 3) + cm, 0), 0xFF) << 16
068                                | Math.min(Math.max(y - (cw * 3 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) << 8
069                                | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
070        }
071
072        /**
073         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
074         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
075         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
076         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
077         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
078         */
079        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
080        {
081                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed), y = (decoded & 0xff),
082                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff),
083                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >> 1);
084                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(Math.min(Math.max(y + (cw * 5 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF)
085                                | Math.min(Math.max(y - (cw * 3 >> 3) + cm, 0), 0xFF) << 8
086                                | Math.min(Math.max(y - (cw * 3 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) << 16
087                                | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
088        }
089
090        /**
091         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the YCwCm this uses.
092         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
093         * @return a packed float as YCwCm, which this class can use
094         */
095        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
096                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((rgba >>> 24) * 3 + (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 4 + (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) >> 3)
097                                | (0xFF + (rgba >>> 24) - (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) & 0x1FE) << 7
098                                | (0xFF + (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) - (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) & 0x1FE) << 15
099                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
100        }
101
102        /**
103         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the YCwCm this uses.
104         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
105         * @return a packed float as YCwCm, which this class can use
106         */
107        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
108                final int rgba = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
109                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((rgba & 0xFF) * 3 + (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 4 + (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) >> 3)
110                                | (0xFF + (rgba & 0xFF) - (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) & 0x1FE) << 7
111                                | (0xFF + (rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) - (rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) & 0x1FE) << 15
112                                | (rgba >>> 24 & 0xFE) << 24);
113        }
114
115        /**
116         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the YCwCm this uses.
117         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
118         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
119         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
120         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
121         * @return a packed float as YCwCm, which this class can use
122         */
123        public static float fromRGBA(final float r, final float g, final float b, final float a) {
124                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((int) (255 * (r * 0x3p-3f + g * 0x4p-3f + b * 0x1p-3f)) & 0xFF
125                                                | (int)((r - b + 1f) * 127.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00
126                                                | (int)((g - b + 1f) * 127.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000
127                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
128        }
129
130        /**
131         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
132         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
133         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
134         */
135        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
136        {
137                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
138                return (decoded & 0xff) + (((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) * 5 >>> 4) - (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >>> 2);
139        }
140
141        /**
142         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
143         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
144         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
145         */
146        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
147        {
148                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
149                return (decoded & 0xff) - (((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) * 3 >> 4) + (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >> 2);
150        }
151
152        /**
153         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
154         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
155         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
156         */
157        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
158        {
159                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
160                return (decoded & 0xff) - (((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) * 3 >> 4) - (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >> 2);
161        }
162
163        /**
164         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
165         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
166         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
167         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
168         */
169        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
170        {
171                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
172        }
173
174        /**
175         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
176         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
177         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
178         */
179        public static float red(final float encoded)
180        {
181                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
182                return Math.min(Math.max((decoded & 0xff) * 0x1.010102p-8f + ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0x1.414142p-9f) - ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * 0x1.010102p-9f, 0f), 1f);
183        }
184
185        /**
186         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
187         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
188         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
189         */
190        public static float green(final float encoded)
191        {
192                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
193                return Math.min(Math.max((decoded & 0xff) * 0x1.010102p-8f - (((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * 0x1.818184p-10f) + ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * 0x1.010102p-9f, 0f), 1f);
194        }
195
196        /**
197         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
198         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
199         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
200         */
201        public static float blue(final float encoded)
202        {
203                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
204                return Math.min(Math.max((decoded & 0xff) * 0x1.010102p-8f - (((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * 0x1.818184p-10f) - ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * 0x1.010102p-9f, 0f), 1f);
205        }
206
207        /**
208         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
209         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
210         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
211         */
212        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
213        {
214                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0.003937008f;
215        }
216
217
218        /**
219         * Gets a color as a YCwCm packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
220         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
221         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
222         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
223         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
224         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
225         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
226         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
227         *
228         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
229         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
230         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
231         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
232         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
233         */
234        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
235                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
236                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
237                } else {
238                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
239                }
240        }
241
242        /**
243         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
244         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
245         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
246         */
247        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
248                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded), lu = (decoded & 0xff),
249                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff),
250                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >> 1);
251                final float r = Math.min(Math.max(lu + (cw * 5 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
252                final float g = Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) + cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
253                final float b =  Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
254                float x, y, w;
255                if(g < b) {
256                        x = b;
257                        y = g;
258                }
259                else {
260                        x = g;
261                        y = b;
262                }
263                if(r < x) {
264                        w = r;
265                }
266                else {
267                        w = x;
268                        x = r;
269                }
270                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
271                float li = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
272                return (x - li) / (Math.min(li, 1f - li) + 1e-10f);
273        }
274
275        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
276                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded), lu = (decoded & 0xff),
277                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff),
278                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >> 1);
279                final float r = Math.min(Math.max(lu + (cw * 5 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
280                final float g = Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) + cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
281                final float b =  Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
282                float x, y, w;
283                if(g < b) {
284                        x = b;
285                        y = g;
286                }
287                else {
288                        x = g;
289                        y = b;
290                }
291                if(r < x) {
292                        w = r;
293                }
294                else {
295                        w = x;
296                        x = r;
297                }
298                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
299                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
300        }
301
302        /**
303         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
304         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
305         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
306         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
307         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
308         */
309        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
310                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded), lu = (decoded & 0xff),
311                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff),
312                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >> 1);
313                final float r = Math.min(Math.max(lu + (cw * 5 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
314                final float g = Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) + cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
315                final float b =  Math.min(Math.max(lu - (cw * 3 >> 3) - cm, 0), 0xFF) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
316                float x, y, z, w;
317                if(g < b) {
318                        x = b;
319                        y = g;
320                        z = -1f;
321                        w = 2f / 3f;
322                }
323                else {
324                        x = g;
325                        y = b;
326                        z = 0f;
327                        w = -1f / 3f;
328                }
329                if(r < x) {
330                        z = w;
331                        w = r;
332                }
333                else {
334                        w = x;
335                        x = r;
336                }
337                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
338                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
339        }
340
341        /**
342         * The "luma" of the given packed float in YCwCm format, which is like its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
343         * 1.0f . YCwCm is useful for modifications to colors:
344         * <ul>
345         *     <li>You can get a grayscale version of a color by setting Cw and Cm to 0.5,</li>
346         *     <li>You can desaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number between 0 and 1, and adding 0.5
347         *     afterwards,</li>
348         *     <li>you can oversaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number greater than 1, and adding 0.5
349         *     afterwards,</li>
350         *     <li>you can lighten or darken by increasing or decreasing luma,</li>
351         *     <li>and so on and so forth.</li>
352         * </ul>
353         * @param encoded a packed float
354         * @return the luma as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
355         */
356        public static float luma(final float encoded)
357        {
358                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
359//        final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
360//        return (bits & 0xFF) * 0x3p-11f + (bits >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1p-9f + (bits >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1p-11f;
361        }
362
363        /**
364         * The "chroma warm" of the given packed float in YCwCm format, which when combined with chroma mild describes the
365         * shade and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . YCwCm is useful for modifications to colors:
366         * <ul>
367         *     <li>You can get a grayscale version of a color by setting Cw and Cm to 0.5,</li>
368         *     <li>You can desaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number between 0 and 1, and adding 0.5
369         *     afterwards,</li>
370         *     <li>you can oversaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number greater than 1, and adding 0.5
371         *     afterwards,</li>
372         *     <li>you can lighten or darken by increasing or decreasing luma,</li>
373         *     <li>and so on and so forth.</li>
374         * </ul>
375         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
376         * @return the chroma warm as a float from 0f to 1f
377         */
378        public static float chromaWarm(final float encoded)
379        {
380                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
381        }
382
383        /**
384         * The "chroma mild" of the given packed float in YCwCm format, which when combined with chroma warm describes the
385         * shade and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f .
386         * YCwCm is useful for modifications to colors:
387         * <ul>
388         *     <li>You can get a grayscale version of a color by setting Cw and Cm to 0.5,</li>
389         *     <li>You can desaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number between 0 and 1, and adding 0.5
390         *     afterwards,</li>
391         *     <li>you can oversaturate by subtracting 0.5, multiplying Cw and Cm by a number greater than 1, and adding 0.5
392         *     afterwards,</li>
393         *     <li>you can lighten or darken by increasing or decreasing luma,</li>
394         *     <li>and so on and so forth.</li>
395         * </ul>
396         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
397         * @return the chroma mild as a float from 0f to 1f
398         */
399        public static float chromaMild(final float encoded)
400        {
401                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
402        }
403
404        /**
405         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
406         * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not YCwCm! Takes
407         * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
408         * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color. The float is
409         * likely to be different than the result of {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation,
410         * lightness, and opacity are all 0. This won't allocate any objects.
411         * <br>
412         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
413         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
414         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
415         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
416         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
417         *
418         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
419         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
420         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
421         * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
422         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
423         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
424         */
425        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
426                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
427                opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (e >>> 24 & 0xfe) * 0x1.020408p-8f, 0f), 1f);
428                if (light + (e & 0xff) * 0x1.010102p-8f <= 0.001f)
429                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
430                final int lu = (e & 0xff);
431                final int cw = ((e >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff);
432                final int cm = (((e >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) >> 1);
433                final float r = Math.min(Math.max(lu + light + (cw * 0.625f) - cm, 0), 255f) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
434                final float g = Math.min(Math.max(lu + light - (cw * 0.375f) + cm, 0), 255f) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
435                final float b = Math.min(Math.max(lu + light - (cw * 0.375f) - cm, 0), 255f) * 0x1.010102p-8f;
436                float x, y, z, w;
437                if(g < b) {
438                        x = b;
439                        y = g;
440                        z = -1f;
441                        w = 2f / 3f;
442                }
443                else {
444                        x = g;
445                        y = b;
446                        z = 0f;
447                        w = -1f / 3f;
448                }
449                if(r < x) {
450                        z = w;
451                        w = r;
452                }
453                else {
454                        w = x;
455                        x = r;
456                }
457                final float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
458                final float lum = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
459                hue += Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
460                saturation += (x - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
461                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
462        }
463
464        /**
465         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
466         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
467         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
468         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
469         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
470         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
471         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
472         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
473         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
474         */
475        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
476                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), luma = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
477                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (luma + (0xFF - luma) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
478        }
479
480        /**
481         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
482         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
483         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
484         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
485         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
486         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
487         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
488         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
489         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
490         */
491        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
492                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), luma = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
493                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (luma * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
494        }
495
496        /**
497         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (yellow to red) by change. While change
498         * should be between 0f (returnstart as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
499         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
500         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
501         * a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and luma of start
502         * as-is.
503         * @see #cool(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
504         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
505         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
506         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
507         */
508        public static float warm(final float start, final float change) {
509                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), warmth = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
510                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (warmth + (0xFF - warmth) * change) << 8 & 0xFF) | other);
511        }
512
513        /**
514         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
515         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
516         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
517         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
518         * a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and luma of start
519         * as-is.
520         * @see #warm(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
521         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
522         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
523         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
524         */
525        public static float cool(final float start, final float change) {
526                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), warmth = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
527                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (warmth * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
528        }
529
530        /**
531         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a milder color (between green and yellow) by change. While
532         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully mild), start should be a packed color, as
533         * from {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
534         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
535         * towards a milder color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and luma of
536         * start as-is.
537         * @see #strengthen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more bold
538         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
539         * @param change how much to change start to a milder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a milder result
540         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a milder color
541         */
542        public static float weaken(final float start, final float change) {
543                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), warmth = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
544                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (warmth + (0xFF - warmth) * change) << 8 & 0xFF) | other);
545        }
546
547        /**
548         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a bolder color (between blue and red) by change. While
549         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as
550         * from {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
551         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
552         * towards a bolder color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and luma of
553         * start as-is.
554         * @see #weaken(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more mild
555         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
556         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a bolder result
557         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a bolder color
558         */
559        public static float strengthen(final float start, final float change) {
560                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), warmth = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
561                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (warmth * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
562        }
563
564        /**
565         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
566         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
567         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
568         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
569         * transparent. This won't change the luma, chroma warm, or chroma mild of the color.
570         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
571         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
572         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
573         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
574         */
575        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
576                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
577                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
578        }
579
580        /**
581         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
582         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
583         * {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
584         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
585         * transparent. This won't change the luma, chroma warm, or chroma mild of the color.
586         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
587         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
588         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
589         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
590         */
591        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
592                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
593                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
594        }
595
596        /**
597         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
598         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
599         * from {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes Cw and Cm; it leaves Y and alpha alone, unlike
600         * {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes Y.
601         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
602         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
603         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
604         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
605         */
606        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
607                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
608                return ycwcm((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
609                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
610                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
611                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
612        }
613
614        /**
615         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
616         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
617         * from {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}. This usually changes only Cw and Cm, but higher values for
618         * {@code change} can force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using
619         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)} (and that can change Y somewhat). If the color stays in-gamut,
620         * then Y won't change; alpha never changes.
621         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
622         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
623         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
624         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
625         */
626        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
627                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
628                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
629                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
630                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
631                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
632        }
633
634        /**
635         * Given a packed float YCwCm color {@code mainColor} and another YCwCm color that it should be made to contrast
636         * with, gets a packed float YCwCm color with roughly inverted luma but the same chromatic channels and opacity (Cw
637         * and Cm are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or
638         * other very dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for luma values between 0.5 and 0.55. That
639         * allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
640         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the luma unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
641         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
642         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
643         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
644         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
645         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}; this is the color that will be adjusted
646         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
647         * @return a different packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
648         */
649        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
650        {
651                final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
652                                contrastBits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
653                                luma = (bits & 0xff),
654                                warm = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
655                                mild = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
656                                cLuma = (contrastBits & 0xff),
657                                cWarm = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
658                                cMild = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
659                if((warm - cWarm) * (warm - cWarm) + (mild - cMild) * (mild - cMild) >= 0x10000)
660                        return mainColor;
661                return ycwcm(cLuma < 128 ? luma * (0.45f / 255f) + 0.55f : 0.5f - luma * (0.45f / 255f), warm / 255f, mild / 255f, 0x1.010102p-8f * (bits >>> 24));
662        }
663
664        /**
665         * Given a packed float YCwCm color {@code mainColor} and another YCwCm color that it should be made to contrast
666         * with, gets a packed float YCwCm color with Y that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s Y,
667         * but the same chromatic channels and opacity (Cw and Cm are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white
668         * or black). This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on
669         * a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
670         * <br>
671         * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
672         * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
673         * averages the original Y of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
674         * @param mainColor a packed YCwCm float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
675         * @param contrastingColor a packed YCwCm float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the Y of this
676         * @return a different packed YCwCm float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
677         */
678        public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
679        {
680                final int main = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
681                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1));
682        }
683
684        /**
685         * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's Y and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
686         * with the original Y. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
687         * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
688         * @param mainColor a packed YCwCm float color
689         * @return a different packed YCwCm float color, with its Y channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
690         */
691        public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
692                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
693                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFEFFFF00) | (decoded + 128 & 0xFF) + (decoded & 0xFF) >>> 1));
694        }
695
696        /**
697         * Makes the additive YCwCm color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
698         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
699         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
700         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
701         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
702         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
703         * @return a YCwCm float color between gray and {@code color}
704         */
705        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
706                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color),
707                                ys = 0x7F, cws = 0x7F, cms = 0x7F,
708                                ye = (e & 0xFF), cwe = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, cme = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, ae = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
709                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (ys + fraction * (ye - ys)) & 0xFF)
710                                | (((int) (cws + fraction * (cwe - cws)) & 0xFF) << 8)
711                                | (((int) (cms + fraction * (cme - cms)) & 0xFF) << 16)
712                                | (ae << 24));
713        }
714        /**
715         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
716         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
717         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
718         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
719         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the Y, Cw, and Cm of the
720         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
721         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers Cw and Cm extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while Y goes from 0 to
722         * 1, but only internally for measuring distance).
723         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}
724         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
725         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
726         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
727         */
728        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
729                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color);
730                final float y = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
731                final float cw = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
732                final float cm = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
733                final float limit = variance * variance;
734                float dist = limit + 1f, a = 0, b = 0, c = 0;
735                while (dist > limit){
736                        a = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
737                        b = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
738                        c = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
739                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
740                        dist = a * a + b * b + c * c;
741                }
742                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(Math.min(Math.max(cm + c, -1), 1) * 127.5f + 128f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
743                                | ((int)(Math.min(Math.max(cw + b, -1), 1) * 127.5f + 128f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(Math.min(Math.max(y + a, 0), 1) * 255f));
744        }
745
746        /**
747         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as YCwCm, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA. 
748         * @param packed a packed float color as YCwCm
749         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
750         */
751        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
752        {
753                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed), y = (decoded & 0xff),
754                                cw = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff),
755                                cm = (((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) / 2);
756                final int r = y + (cw * 5 / 8) - cm;
757                if(r < 0 || r > 255) return false;
758                final int g = y - (cw * 3 / 8) + cm;
759                if(g < 0 || g > 255) return false;
760                final int b = y - (cw * 3 / 8) - cm;
761                return (b >= 0) && (b <= 255);
762        }
763        /**
764         * Returns true if the given YCwCm values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA. 
765         * @param y luma channel, as a float from 0 to 1
766         * @param cw chromatic warmth channel, as a float from 0 to 1
767         * @param cm chromatic mildness channel, as a float from 0 to 1
768         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
769         */
770        public static boolean inGamut(float y, float cw, float cm)
771        {
772                final int yi = (int)(y * 255.999f), cwi = (int) ((cw - 0.5f) * 511.999f), cmi = (int) ((cm - 0.5f) * 255.999f);
773                final int r = yi + (cwi * 5 / 8) - cmi;
774                if(r < 0 || r > 255) return false;
775                final int g = yi - (cwi * 3 / 8) + cmi;
776                if(g < 0 || g > 255) return false;
777                final int b = yi - (cwi * 3 / 8) - cmi;
778                return (b >= 0) && (b <= 255);
779        }
780
781        /**
782         * Iteratively checks whether the given YCwCm color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if
783         * it isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
784         * @param packed a packed float color in YCwCm format; often this color is not in-gamut
785         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given YCwCm color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
786         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
787         */
788        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
789                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
790                final float y = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
791                final float cw = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
792                final float cm = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 255f;
793                float cw2 = cw, cm2 = cm;
794                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
795                        final float r = y + 0.625f * cw2 - cm2;
796                        final float g = y - 0.375f * cw2 + cm2;
797                        final float b = y - 0.375f * cw2 - cm2;
798                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
799                                break;
800                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
801                        cw2 = MathTools.lerp(0, cw, progress);
802                        cm2 = MathTools.lerp(0, cm, progress);
803                }
804                return ycwcm(y, cw2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, cm2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
805        }
806
807        /**
808         * Iteratively checks whether the given YCwCm color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if
809         * it isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. This always produces an opaque color.
810         * @param y luma component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
811         * @param cw chromatic warmth component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
812         * @param cm chromatic mildness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
813         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given YCwCm color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
814         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
815         */
816        public static float limitToGamut(float y, float cw, float cm) {
817                return limitToGamut(y, cw, cm, 1f);
818        }
819
820        /**
821         * Iteratively checks whether the given YCwCm color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to 50% gray if
822         * it isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut.
823         * @param y luma component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
824         * @param cw chromatic warmth component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
825         * @param cm chromatic mildness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
826         * @param a alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
827         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given YCwCm color and 50% gray, and is in-gamut
828         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
829         */
830        public static float limitToGamut(float y, float cw, float cm, float a)
831        {
832                float y2 = Math.min(Math.max(y, 0f), 1f);
833                float cw2 = cw = Math.min(Math.max((cw - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
834                float cm2 = cm = Math.min(Math.max((cm - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
835                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
836                        final float r = y2 + 0.625f * cw2 - cm2;
837                        final float g = y2 - 0.375f * cw2 + cm2;
838                        final float b = y2 - 0.375f * cw2 - cm2;
839                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
840                                break;
841                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
842                        cw2 = MathTools.lerp(0, cw, progress);
843                        cm2 = MathTools.lerp(0, cm, progress);
844                }
845                return ycwcm(y2, cw2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, cm2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, Math.min(Math.max(a, 0f), 1f));
846        }
847
848        /**
849         * Given a packed float YCwCm color, this edits its luma (Y), chromatic warmth (Cw), chromatic mildness (Cm), and
850         * alpha channels by adding the corresponding "add" parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float
851         * value (of course, the given float can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter
852         * you want to stay unchanged. This clamps the resulting color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert
853         * it back to RGBA.
854         * @param encoded a packed float YCwCm color
855         * @param addY how much to add to the luma channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
856         * @param addCw how much to add to the chromatic warmth channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
857         * @param addCm how much to add to the chromatic mildness channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
858         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
859         * @return a packed float YCwCm color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
860         */
861        public static float editYCwCm(float encoded, float addY, float addCw, float addCm, float addAlpha) {
862                return editYCwCm(encoded, addY, addCw, addCm, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
863        }
864        /**
865         * Given a packed float YCwCm color, this edits its luma (Y), chromatic warmth (Cw), chromatic mildness (Cm), and
866         * alpha channels by first multiplying each channel by the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the
867         * corresponding "add" parameter, before clamping. This means the luma value is multiplied by {@code mulY}, then has
868         * {@code addY} added, and then is clamped to the normal range for luma (0 to 1). This returns a different float
869         * value (of course, the given float can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter
870         * you want to stay unchanged, or a value of 1 for any "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. Note that this
871         * manipulates chromatic warmth and mildness in the -1 to 1 range, so if you multiply by a small number like
872         * {@code 0.25f}, then this will produce a less-saturated color, and if you multiply by a larger number like
873         * {@code 4f}, then you will get a much more-saturated color. This clamps the resulting color to remain in-gamut,
874         * so it should be safe to convert it back to RGBA.
875         * @param encoded a packed float YCwCm color
876         * @param addY how much to add to the luma channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
877         * @param addCw how much to add to the chromatic warmth channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
878         * @param addCm how much to add to the chromatic mildness channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
879         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
880         * @param mulY how much to multiply the luma channel by; should be non-negative
881         * @param mulCw how much to multiply the chromatic warmth channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
882         * @param mulCm how much to multiply the chromatic mildness channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
883         * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
884         * @return a packed float YCwCm color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
885         */
886        public static float editYCwCm(float encoded, float addY, float addCw, float addCm, float addAlpha,
887                                                                  float mulY, float mulCw, float mulCm, float mulAlpha) {
888                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
889                float y = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
890                float cw = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
891                float cm = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
892                float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
893
894                float y2 = Math.min(Math.max(y * mulY + addY, 0f), 1f);
895                float cw2 = cw = Math.min(Math.max(cw * mulCw + addCw, -1f), 1f);
896                float cm2 = cm = Math.min(Math.max(cm * mulCm + addCm, -1f), 1f);
897                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
898                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
899                        final float r = y2 + 0.625f * cw2 - cm2;
900                        final float g = y2 - 0.375f * cw2 + cm2;
901                        final float b = y2 - 0.375f * cw2 - cm2;
902                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
903                                break;
904                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
905                        cw2 = MathTools.lerp(0, cw, progress);
906                        cm2 = MathTools.lerp(0, cm, progress);
907                }
908                return ycwcm(y2, cw2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, cm2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, alpha);
909        }
910
911        /**
912         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
913         * @param random a Random object (or preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.digital.AlternateRandom})
914         * @return a random opaque packed float color that is always in-gamut
915         */
916        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
917                final float yr = +0.375f, wr = +0.5f, mr = +0.0f;
918                final float yg = +0.500f, wg = +0.0f, mg = +0.5f;
919                final float yb = +0.125f, wb = -0.5f, mb = -0.5f;
920                final float r = random.nextFloat(), g = random.nextFloat(), b = random.nextFloat();
921                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
922                                | ((int) ((mr * r + mg * g + mb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
923                                | ((int) ((wr * r + wg * g + wb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
924                                | ((int) ((yr * r + yg * g + yb * b) * 256f) & 0xFF));
925        }
926
927        /**
928         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
929         * This is only present for legacy compatibility; new code should use {@link #randomColor(Random)}.
930         * @param random a Random object (or preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.digital.AlternateRandom})
931         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
932         * @deprecated Use {@link #randomColor(Random)} instead.
933         */
934        @Deprecated
935        public static float randomizedColor(Random random) {
936                final float yr = +0.375f, wr = +0.5f, mr = +0.0f;
937                final float yg = +0.500f, wg = +0.0f, mg = +0.5f;
938                final float yb = +0.125f, wb = -0.5f, mb = -0.5f;
939                final float r = random.nextFloat(), g = random.nextFloat(), b = random.nextFloat();
940                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
941                                | ((int) ((mr * r + mg * g + mb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
942                                | ((int) ((wr * r + wg * g + wb * b) * 128f + 128f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
943                                | ((int) ((yr * r + yg * g + yb * b) * 256f) & 0xFF));
944        }
945}
